Hello hashtag#Connections,We are hashtag#hiring for "Data Modeler" role for one of our client in Hongkong.Applications are welcome from candidates who are having full work rights in Hongkong.Key Responsibilities:- Design, develop, and maintain data models to support various business processes.- Work closely with stakeholders to understand data requirements and translate them into efficient models.- Implement and optimize Extract, Transform, Load (ETL) processes to ensure timely and accurate data flows.- Leverage Tableau to create interactive dashboards and visualizations for data insights andreporting.- Manage data infrastructure on AWS, ensuring scalability, security, and performance.- Perform data quality assessments and apply best practices to maintain data accuracy and consistency.- Collaborate with cross-functional teams, including data engineers, analysts, and business leaders, to support data-driven decision-making.Qualifications:- Bachelor’s degree in computer science, Information Systems, or a related eld.- Proven experience (5 years) in data modelling, database design, and data architecture.- Expertise in Tableau for data visualization and dashboard creation.- Proficient in AWS services related to data storage, processing, and security.- Strong experience with ETL processes and tools.- Solid understanding of relational and non-relational databases.- Analytical thinking with excellent problem-solving skills.- Strong communication skills to collaborate with technical and non-technical stakeholders.Alternatively, you can share your resume to sea.team@poweritservices.com OR reach out on WhatsApp +91 89259 25692 to discuss.

Can Tesla Survive 2025? 3 Red Flags Investors Shouldn’t Ignore📺 Watch the full video breakdown here → https://lnkd.in/gQPvrgwnTesla has always been a company that thrives on bold moves and ambitious visions—but as we head deeper into 2025, some critical challenges are emerging. In this post, we’ll explore three major developments that could significantly impact Tesla’s future—and what they mean for investors, owners, and fans of the company.⚠️ 1. Tesla’s Market Share in California Is Dropping FastCalifornia has long been Tesla’s stronghold—but recent data reveals a worrying trend. In Q1 2025, Tesla’s share of the EV market in California dropped to 43.9%, down from 55.5% a year earlier. That’s a 12-point decline in just one year.While Tesla’s registrations fell by 15%, other EV makers saw a 35% surge. The takeaway? Tesla isn’t just slowing down—its rivals are speeding up.Industry experts point to two main reasons:Tesla’s product lineup is aging, with limited updates to Models S, X, 3, and Y.Elon Musk’s political and social media activity may be turning off some buyers.While Model Y and Model 3 remain best-sellers, declining market share could impact resale values and Tesla’s overall brand power.💥 2. Cybercab and Semi Face Delays Due to TariffsAnother red flag: new tariffs may disrupt Tesla’s ambitious plans for next-gen vehicles like the Cybercab and the Semi truck.Reports indicate that tariffs on Chinese-made parts could rise as high as 145% under new trade policies. In response, Tesla has reportedly halted parts imports from China—potentially delaying the October 2025 prototype production and pushing back mass production to 2026.Tesla had previously absorbed tariffs up to 34%, but beyond that, costs become unsustainable.However, despite these hurdles, Tesla isn’t slowing down. The company is actively hiring for its Robotaxi division, including roles like Diagnostics Engineer, Robotaxi Operations—a clear sign it’s still investing in autonomous driving as a long-term growth engine.🌏 3. Can Tesla Survive 2025? 3 Red Flags Investors Shouldn’t Ignore📺 Watch the full video breakdown here → https://lnkd.in/gQPvrgwnTesla has always been a company that thrives on bold moves and ambitious visions—but as we head deeper into 2025, some critical challenges are emerging. In this post, we’ll explore three major developments that could significantly impact Tesla’s future—and what they mean for investors, owners, and fans of the company.⚠️ 1. Tesla’s Market Share in California Is Dropping FastCalifornia has long been Tesla’s stronghold—but recent data reveals a worrying trend. In Q1 2025, Tesla’s share of the EV market in California dropped to 43.9%, down from 55.5% a year earlier. That’s a 12-point decline in just one year.While Tesla’s registrations fell by 15%, other EV makers saw a 35% surge. The takeaway? Tesla isn’t just slowing down—its rivals are speeding up.Industry experts point to two main reasons:Tesla’s product lineup is aging, with limited updates to Models S, X, 3, and Y.Elon Musk’s political and social media activity may be turning off some buyers.While Model Y and Model 3 remain best-sellers, declining market share could impact resale values and Tesla’s overall brand power.💥 2. Cybercab and Semi Face Delays Due to TariffsAnother red flag: new tariffs may disrupt Tesla’s ambitious plans for next-gen vehicles like the Cybercab and the Semi truck.Reports indicate that tariffs on Chinese-made parts could rise as high as 145% under new trade policies. In response, Tesla has reportedly halted parts imports from China—potentially delaying the October 2025 prototype production and pushing back mass production to 2026.Tesla had previously absorbed tariffs up to 34%, but beyond that, costs become unsustainable.However, despite these hurdles, Tesla isn’t slowing down. The company is actively hiring for its Robotaxi division, including roles like Diagnostics Engineer, Robotaxi Operations—a clear sign it’s still investing in autonomous driving as a long-term growth engine.🌏 3. Tesla Accelerates Its Expansion Into IndiaWhile Tesla faces challenges in California and with supply chains, it’s also entering a massive new market—India.The company has posted over 25 job openings in India, many related to charging infrastructure, battery materials, and supply chain operations—not just retail or sales.One job listing specifically mentioned expertise in LFP and NMC battery materials, hinting that Tesla may be planning to source or produce batteries locally.Adding to the excitement, the Model Y was spotted test-driving in Mumbai, suggesting real-world trials are already underway.With over 1.4 billion people and a fast-growing demand for EVs, India has the potential to become Tesla’s next big growth engine—alongside the U.S. and China.

Can Tesla Survive 2025? 3 Red Flags Investors Shouldn’t Ignore📺 Watch the full video breakdown here → https://lnkd.in/gQPvrgwnTesla has always been a company that thrives on bold moves and ambitious visions—but as we head deeper into 2025, some critical challenges are emerging. In this post, we’ll explore three major developments that could significantly impact Tesla’s future—and what they mean for investors, owners, and fans of the company.⚠️ 1. Tesla’s Market Share in California Is Dropping FastCalifornia has long been Tesla’s stronghold—but recent data reveals a worrying trend. In Q1 2025, Tesla’s share of the EV market in California dropped to 43.9%, down from 55.5% a year earlier. That’s a 12-point decline in just one year.While Tesla’s registrations fell by 15%, other EV makers saw a 35% surge. The takeaway? Tesla isn’t just slowing down—its rivals are speeding up.Industry experts point to two main reasons:Tesla’s product lineup is aging, with limited updates to Models S, X, 3, and Y.Elon Musk’s political and social media activity may be turning off some buyers.While Model Y and Model 3 remain best-sellers, declining market share could impact resale values and Tesla’s overall brand power.💥 2. Cybercab and Semi Face Delays Due to TariffsAnother red flag: new tariffs may disrupt Tesla’s ambitious plans for next-gen vehicles like the Cybercab and the Semi truck.Reports indicate that tariffs on Chinese-made parts could rise as high as 145% under new trade policies. In response, Tesla has reportedly halted parts imports from China—potentially delaying the October 2025 prototype production and pushing back mass production to 2026.Tesla had previously absorbed tariffs up to 34%, but beyond that, costs become unsustainable.However, despite these hurdles, Tesla isn’t slowing down. The company is actively hiring for its Robotaxi division, including roles like Diagnostics Engineer, Robotaxi Operations—a clear sign it’s still investing in autonomous driving as a long-term growth engine.🌏 3. Tesla Accelerates Its Expansion Into IndiaWhile Tesla faces challenges in California and with supply chains, it’s also entering a massive new market—India.The company has posted over 25 job openings in India, many related to charging infrastructure, battery materials, and supply chain operations—not just retail or sales.One job listing specifically mentioned expertise in LFP and NMC battery materials, hinting that Tesla may be planning to source or produce batteries locally.Adding to the excitement, the Model Y was spotted test-driving in Mumbai, suggesting real-world trials are already underway.With over 1.4 billion people and a fast-growing demand for EVs, India has the potential to become Tesla’s next big growth engine—alongside the U.S. and China.

Can Tesla Survive 2025? 3 Red Flags Investors Shouldn’t Ignore📺 Watch the full video breakdown here → https://lnkd.in/gQPvrgwnTesla has always been a company that thrives on bold moves and ambitious visions—but as we head deeper into 2025, some critical challenges are emerging. In this post, we’ll explore three major developments that could significantly impact Tesla’s future—and what they mean for investors, owners, and fans of the company.⚠️ 1. Tesla’s Market Share in California Is Dropping FastCalifornia has long been Tesla’s stronghold—but recent data reveals a worrying trend. In Q1 2025, Tesla’s share of the EV market in California dropped to 43.9%, down from 55.5% a year earlier. That’s a 12-point decline in just one year.While Tesla’s registrations fell by 15%, other EV makers saw a 35% surge. The takeaway? Tesla isn’t just slowing down—its rivals are speeding up.Industry experts point to two main reasons:Tesla’s product lineup is aging, with limited updates to Models S, X, 3, and Y.Elon Musk’s political and social media activity may be turning off some buyers.While Model Y and Model 3 remain best-sellers, declining market share could impact resale values and Tesla’s overall brand power.💥 2. Cybercab and Semi Face Delays Due to TariffsAnother red flag: new tariffs may disrupt Tesla’s ambitious plans for next-gen vehicles like the Cybercab and the Semi truck.Reports indicate that tariffs on Chinese-made parts could rise as high as 145% under new trade policies. In response, Tesla has reportedly halted parts imports from China—potentially delaying the October 2025 prototype production and pushing back mass production to 2026.Tesla had previously absorbed tariffs up to 34%, but beyond that, costs become unsustainable.However, despite these hurdles, Tesla isn’t slowing down. The company is actively hiring for its Robotaxi division, including roles like Diagnostics Engineer, Robotaxi Operations—a clear sign it’s still investing in autonomous driving as a long-term growth engine.🌏 3. Tesla Accelerates Its Expansion Into IndiaWhile Tesla faces challenges in California and with supply chains, it’s also entering a massive new market—India.The company has posted over 25 job openings in India, many related to charging infrastructure, battery materials, and supply chain operations—not just retail or sales.One job listing specifically mentioned expertise in LFP and NMC battery materials, hinting that Tesla may be planning to source or produce batteries locally.Adding to the excitement, the Model Y was spotted test-driving in Mumbai, suggesting real-world trials are already underway.With over 1.4 billion people and a fast-growing demand for EVs, India has the potential to become Tesla’s next big growth engine—alongside the U.S. and China.

Can Tesla Survive 2025? 3 Red Flags Investors Shouldn’t Ignore📺 Watch the full video breakdown here → https://lnkd.in/gQPvrgwnTesla has always been a company that thrives on bold moves and ambitious visions—but as we head deeper into 2025, some critical challenges are emerging. In this post, we’ll explore three major developments that could significantly impact Tesla’s future—and what they mean for investors, owners, and fans of the company.⚠️ 1. Tesla’s Market Share in California Is Dropping FastCalifornia has long been Tesla’s stronghold—but recent data reveals a worrying trend. In Q1 2025, Tesla’s share of the EV market in California dropped to 43.9%, down from 55.5% a year earlier. That’s a 12-point decline in just one year.While Tesla’s registrations fell by 15%, other EV makers saw a 35% surge. The takeaway? Tesla isn’t just slowing down—its rivals are speeding up.Industry experts point to two main reasons:Tesla’s product lineup is aging, with limited updates to Models S, X, 3, and Y.Elon Musk’s political and social media activity may be turning off some buyers.While Model Y and Model 3 remain best-sellers, declining market share could impact resale values and Tesla’s overall brand power.💥 2. Cybercab and Semi Face Delays Due to TariffsAnother red flag: new tariffs may disrupt Tesla’s ambitious plans for next-gen vehicles like the Cybercab and the Semi truck.Reports indicate that tariffs on Chinese-made parts could rise as high as 145% under new trade policies. In response, Tesla has reportedly halted parts imports from China—potentially delaying the October 2025 prototype production and pushing back mass production to 2026.Tesla had previously absorbed tariffs up to 34%, but beyond that, costs become unsustainable.However, despite these hurdles, Tesla isn’t slowing down. The company is actively hiring for its Robotaxi division, including roles like Diagnostics Engineer, Robotaxi Operations—a clear sign it’s still investing in autonomous driving as a long-term growth engine.🌏 3. Tesla Accelerates Its Expansion Into IndiaWhile Tesla faces challenges in California and with supply chains, it’s also entering a massive new market—India.The company has posted over 25 job openings in India, many related to charging infrastructure, battery materials, and supply chain operations—not just retail or sales.One job listing specifically mentioned expertise in LFP and NMC battery materials, hinting that Tesla may be planning to source or produce batteries locally.Adding to the excitement, the Model Y was spotted test-driving in Mumbai, suggesting real-world trials are already underway.With over 1.4 billion people and a fast-growing demand for EVs, India has the potential to become Tesla’s next big growth engine—alongside the U.S. and China.

Can Tesla Survive 2025? 3 Red Flags Investors Shouldn’t Ignore📺 Watch the full video breakdown here → https://lnkd.in/gQPvrgwnTesla has always been a company that thrives on bold moves and ambitious visions—but as we head deeper into 2025, some critical challenges are emerging. In this post, we’ll explore three major developments that could significantly impact Tesla’s future—and what they mean for investors, owners, and fans of the company.⚠️ 1. Tesla’s Market Share in California Is Dropping FastCalifornia has long been Tesla’s stronghold—but recent data reveals a worrying trend. In Q1 2025, Tesla’s share of the EV market in California dropped to 43.9%, down from 55.5% a year earlier. That’s a 12-point decline in just one year.While Tesla’s registrations fell by 15%, other EV makers saw a 35% surge. The takeaway? Tesla isn’t just slowing down—its rivals are speeding up.Industry experts point to two main reasons:Tesla’s product lineup is aging, with limited updates to Models S, X, 3, and Y.Elon Musk’s political and social media activity may be turning off some buyers.While Model Y and Model 3 remain best-sellers, declining market share could impact resale values and Tesla’s overall brand power.💥 2. Cybercab and Semi Face Delays Due to TariffsAnother red flag: new tariffs may disrupt Tesla’s ambitious plans for next-gen vehicles like the Cybercab and the Semi truck.Reports indicate that tariffs on Chinese-made parts could rise as high as 145% under new trade policies. In response, Tesla has reportedly halted parts imports from China—potentially delaying the October 2025 prototype production and pushing back mass production to 2026.Tesla had previously absorbed tariffs up to 34%, but beyond that, costs become unsustainable.However, despite these hurdles, Tesla isn’t slowing down. The company is actively hiring for its Robotaxi division, including roles like Diagnostics Engineer, Robotaxi Operations—a clear sign it’s still investing in autonomous driving as a long-term growth engine.🌏 3. Tesla Accelerates Its Expansion Into IndiaWhile Tesla faces challenges in California and with supply chains, it’s also entering a massive new market—India.The company has posted over 25 job openings in India, many related to charging infrastructure, battery materials, and supply chain operations—not just retail or sales.One job listing specifically mentioned expertise in LFP and NMC battery materials, hinting that Tesla may be planning to source or produce batteries locally.Adding to the excitement, the Model Y was spotted test-driving in Mumbai, suggesting real-world trials are already underway.With over 1.4 billion people and a fast-growing demand for EVs, India has the potential to become Tesla’s next big growth engine—alongside the U.S. and China.

With a strong network of government agencies, regulatory bodies, and investment agencies, we guide projects from conception to completion, including site selection and project charters. This position will involve a blend of tasks focused on process improvement, adherence to standards, and ensuring product/service quality. The successful candidate will contribute to maintaining high operational standards and driving continuous improvement initiatives.Key Responsibilities:·      Assist in the development, optimization, and documentation of manufacturing or operational processes.·      Support the implementation of process improvements and efficiency initiatives.·      Collect and analyse process data to identify areas for enhancement and potential quality issues.·      Contribute to the creation and maintenance of Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) and work instructions, ensuring quality considerations are integrated.·      Participate in troubleshooting process-related issues, identifying root causes, and implementing corrective and preventive actions (CAPA).·      Assist in process validation and qualification activities.·      Support quality control activities, including inspections and testing, and provide feedback for process improvements.·      Help maintain accurate process and quality documentation and records.·      Support data collection and analysis for both process performance monitoring and quality metrics.·      Assist in ensuring compliance with relevant standards and regulations from both a process and quality perspective.Qualification:·      Degree in Microbiology, Biotechnology, Life Sciences, Pharmaceutical Sciences, Engineering, or related field.·      1–2 years’ experience in pharmaceutical, biotechnology, Semiconductor or Medical Devices manufacturing environments.·      Familiarity with Cleanroom and GMP standards is preferred.·      Strong attention to detail and observation skills.·      Flexible on working arrangement (vary depends on project).·      Good command of English (spoken and written) for documentation and reporting.Potential for Permanent Roles:Successful performance in this role, demonstrating a strong aptitude for both process and quality aspects, may lead to opportunities for permanent positions within the company.Click Can Tesla Survive 2025? 3 Red Flags Investors Shouldn’t Ignore📺 Watch the full video breakdown here → https://lnkd.in/gQPvrgwnTesla has always been a company that thrives on bold moves and ambitious visions—but as we head deeper into 2025, some critical challenges are emerging. In this post, we’ll explore three major developments that could significantly impact Tesla’s future—and what they mean for investors, owners, and fans of the company.⚠️ 1. Tesla’s Market Share in California Is Dropping FastCalifornia has long been Tesla’s stronghold—but recent data reveals a worrying trend. In Q1 2025, Tesla’s share of the EV market in California dropped to 43.9%, down from 55.5% a year earlier. That’s a 12-point decline in just one year.While Tesla’s registrations fell by 15%, other EV makers saw a 35% surge. The takeaway? Tesla isn’t just slowing down—its rivals are speeding up.Industry experts point to two main reasons:Tesla’s product lineup is aging, with limited updates to Models S, X, 3, and Y.Elon Musk’s political and social media activity may be turning off some buyers.While Model Y and Model 3 remain best-sellers, declining market share could impact resale values and Tesla’s overall brand power.💥 2. Cybercab and Semi Face Delays Due to TariffsAnother red flag: new tariffs may disrupt Tesla’s ambitious plans for next-gen vehicles like the Cybercab and the Semi truck.Reports indicate that tariffs on Chinese-made parts could rise as high as 145% under new trade policies. In response, Tesla has reportedly halted parts imports from China—potentially delaying the October 2025 prototype production and pushing back mass production to 2026.Tesla had previously absorbed tariffs up to 34%, but beyond that, costs become unsustainable.However, despite these hurdles, Tesla isn’t slowing down. The company is actively hiring for its Robotaxi division, including roles like Diagnostics Engineer, Robotaxi Operations—a clear sign it’s still investing in autonomous driving as a long-term growth engine.🌏 3. Tesla Accelerates Its Expansion Into IndiaWhile Tesla faces challenges in California and with supply chains, it’s also entering a massive new market—India.The company has posted over 25 job openings in India, many related to charging infrastructure, battery materials, and supply chain operations—not just retail or sales.One job listing specifically mentioned expertise in LFP and NMC battery materials, hinting that Tesla may be planning to source or produce batteries locally.Adding to the excitement, the Model Y was spotted test-driving in Mumbai, suggesting real-world trials are already underway.With over 1.4 billion people and a fast-growing demand for EVs, India has the potential to become Tesla’s next big growth engine—alongside the U.S. and China.

Can Tesla Survive 2025? 3 Red Flags Investors Shouldn’t Ignore📺 Watch the full video breakdown here → https://lnkd.in/gQPvrgwnTesla has always been a company that thrives on bold moves and ambitious visions—but as we head deeper into 2025, some critical challenges are emerging. In this post, we’ll explore three major developments that could significantly impact Tesla’s future—and what they mean for investors, owners, and fans of the company.⚠️ 1. Tesla’s Market Share in California Is Dropping FastCalifornia has long been Tesla’s stronghold—but recent data reveals a worrying trend. In Q1 2025, Tesla’s share of the EV market in California dropped to 43.9%, down from 55.5% a year earlier. That’s a 12-point decline in just one year.While Tesla’s registrations fell by 15%, other EV makers saw a 35% surge. The takeaway? Tesla isn’t just slowing down—its rivals are speeding up.Industry experts point to two main reasons:Tesla’s product lineup is aging, with limited updates to Models S, X, 3, and Y.Elon Musk’s political and social media activity may be turning off some buyers.While Model Y and Model 3 remain best-sellers, declining market share could impact resale values and Tesla’s overall brand power.💥 2. Cybercab and Semi Face Delays Due to TariffsAnother red flag: new tariffs may disrupt Tesla’s ambitious plans for next-gen vehicles like the Cybercab and the Semi truck.Reports indicate that tariffs on Chinese-made parts could rise as high as 145% under new trade policies. In response, Tesla has reportedly halted parts imports from China—potentially delaying the October 2025 prototype production and pushing back mass production to 2026.Tesla had previously absorbed tariffs up to 34%, but beyond that, costs become unsustainable.However, despite these hurdles, Tesla isn’t slowing down. The company is actively hiring for its Robotaxi division, including roles like Diagnostics Engineer, Robotaxi Operations—a clear sign it’s still investing in autonomous driving as a long-term growth engine.🌏 3. Tesla Accelerates Its Expansion Into IndiaWhile Tesla faces challenges in California and with supply chains, it’s also entering a massive new market—India.The company has posted over 25 job openings in India, many related to charging infrastructure, battery materials, and supply chain operations—not just retail or sales.One job listing specifically mentioned expertise in LFP and NMC battery materials, hinting that Tesla may be planning to source or produce batteries locally.Adding to the excitement, the Model Y was spotted test-driving in Mumbai, suggesting real-world trials are already underway.With over 1.4 billion people and a fast-growing demand for EVs, India has the potential to become Tesla’s next big growth engine—alongside the U.S. and China.

Can Tesla Survive 2025? 3 Red Flags Investors Shouldn’t Ignore📺 Watch the full video breakdown here → https://lnkd.in/gQPvrgwnTesla has always been a company that thrives on bold moves and ambitious visions—but as we head deeper into 2025, some critical challenges are emerging. In this post, we’ll explore three major developments that could significantly impact Tesla’s future—and what they mean for investors, owners, and fans of the company.⚠️ 1. Tesla’s Market Share in California Is Dropping FastCalifornia has long been Tesla’s stronghold—but recent data reveals a worrying trend. In Q1 2025, Tesla’s share of the EV market in California dropped to 43.9%, down from 55.5% a year earlier. That’s a 12-point decline in just one year.While Tesla’s registrations fell by 15%, other EV makers saw a 35% surge. The takeaway? Tesla isn’t just slowing down—its rivals are speeding up.Industry experts point to two main reasons:Tesla’s product lineup is aging, with limited updates to Models S, X, 3, and Y.Elon Musk’s political and social media activity may be turning off some buyers.While Model Y and Model 3 remain best-sellers, declining market share could impact resale values and Tesla’s overall brand power.💥 2. Cybercab and Semi Face Delays Due to TariffsAnother red flag: new tariffs may disrupt Tesla’s ambitious plans for next-gen vehicles like the Cybercab and the Semi truck.Reports indicate that tariffs on Chinese-made parts could rise as high as 145% under new trade policies. In response, Tesla has reportedly halted parts imports from China—potentially delaying the October 2025 prototype production and pushing back mass production to 2026.Tesla had previously absorbed tariffs up to 34%, but beyond that, costs become unsustainable.However, despite these hurdles, Tesla isn’t slowing down. The company is actively hiring for its Robotaxi division, including roles like Diagnostics Engineer, Robotaxi Operations—a clear sign it’s still investing in autonomous driving as a long-term growth engine.🌏 3. Tesla Accelerates Its Expansion Into IndiaWhile Tesla faces challenges in California and with supply chains, it’s also entering a massive new market—India.The company has posted over 25 job openings in India, many related to charging infrastructure, battery materials, and supply chain operations—not just retail or sales.One job listing specifically mentioned expertise in LFP and NMC battery materials, hinting that Tesla may be planning to source or produce batteries locally.Adding to the excitement, the Model Y was spotted test-driving in Mumbai, suggesting real-world trials are already underway.With over 1.4 billion people and a fast-growing demand for EVs, India has the potential to become Tesla’s next big growth engine—alongside the U.S. and China.

Can Tesla Survive 2025? 3 Red Flags Investors Shouldn’t Ignore📺 Watch the full video breakdown here → https://lnkd.in/gQPvrgwnTesla has always been a company that thrives on bold moves and ambitious visions—but as we head deeper into 2025, some critical challenges are emerging. In this post, we’ll explore three major developments that could significantly impact Tesla’s future—and what they mean for investors, owners, and fans of the company.⚠️ 1. Tesla’s Market Share in California Is Dropping FastCalifornia has long been Tesla’s stronghold—but recent data reveals a worrying trend. In Q1 2025, Tesla’s share of the EV market in California dropped to 43.9%, down from 55.5% a year earlier. That’s a 12-point decline in just one year.While Tesla’s registrations fell by 15%, other EV makers saw a 35% surge. The takeaway? Tesla isn’t just slowing down—its rivals are speeding up.Industry experts point to two main reasons:Tesla’s product lineup is aging, with limited updates to Models S, X, 3, and Y.Elon Musk’s political and social media activity may be turning off some buyers.While Model Y and Model 3 remain best-sellers, declining market share could impact resale values and Tesla’s overall brand power.💥 2. Cybercab and Semi Face Delays Due to TariffsAnother red flag: new tariffs may disrupt Tesla’s ambitious plans for next-gen vehicles like the Cybercab and the Semi truck.Reports indicate that tariffs on Chinese-made parts could rise as high as 145% under new trade policies. In response, Tesla has reportedly halted parts imports from China—potentially delaying the October 2025 prototype production and pushing back mass production to 2026.Tesla had previously absorbed tariffs up to 34%, but beyond that, costs become unsustainable.However, despite these hurdles, Tesla isn’t slowing down. The company is actively hiring for its Robotaxi division, including roles like Diagnostics Engineer, Robotaxi Operations—a clear sign it’s still investing in autonomous driving as a long-term growth engine.🌏 3. Tesla Accelerates Its Expansion Into IndiaWhile Tesla faces challenges in California and with supply chains, it’s also entering a massive new market—India.The company has posted over 25 job openings in India, many related to charging infrastructure, battery materials, and supply chain operations—not just retail or sales.One job listing specifically mentioned expertise in LFP and NMC battery materials, hinting that Tesla may be planning to source or produce batteries locally.Adding to the excitement, the Model Y was spotted test-driving in Mumbai, suggesting real-world trials are already underway.With over 1.4 billion people and a fast-growing demand for EVs, India has the potential to become Tesla’s next big growth engine—alongside the U.S. and China.

Can Tesla Survive 2025? 3 Red Flags Investors Shouldn’t Ignore📺 Watch the full video breakdown here → https://lnkd.in/gQPvrgwnTesla has always been a company that thrives on bold moves and ambitious visions—but as we head deeper into 2025, some critical challenges are emerging. In this post, we’ll explore three major developments that could significantly impact Tesla’s future—and what they mean for investors, owners, and fans of the company.⚠️ 1. Tesla’s Market Share in California Is Dropping FastCalifornia has long been Tesla’s stronghold—but recent data reveals a worrying trend. In Q1 2025, Tesla’s share of the EV market in California dropped to 43.9%, down from 55.5% a year earlier. That’s a 12-point decline in just one year.While Tesla’s registrations fell by 15%, other EV makers saw a 35% surge. The takeaway? Tesla isn’t just slowing down—its rivals are speeding up.Industry experts point to two main reasons:Tesla’s product lineup is aging, with limited updates to Models S, X, 3, and Y.Elon Musk’s political and social media activity may be turning off some buyers.While Model Y and Model 3 remain best-sellers, declining market share could impact resale values and Tesla’s overall brand power.💥 2. Cybercab and Semi Face Delays Due to TariffsAnother red flag: new tariffs may disrupt Tesla’s ambitious plans for next-gen vehicles like the Cybercab and the Semi truck.Reports indicate that tariffs on Chinese-made parts could rise as high as 145% under new trade policies. In response, Tesla has reportedly halted parts imports from China—potentially delaying the October 2025 prototype production and pushing back mass production to 2026.Tesla had previously absorbed tariffs up to 34%, but beyond that, costs become unsustainable.However, despite these hurdles, Tesla isn’t slowing down. The company is actively hiring for its Robotaxi division, including roles like Diagnostics Engineer, Robotaxi Operations—a clear sign it’s still investing in autonomous driving as a long-term growth engine.🌏 3. Tesla Accelerates Its Expansion Into IndiaWhile Tesla faces challenges in California and with supply chains, it’s also entering a massive new market—India.The company has posted over 25 job openings in India, many related to charging infrastructure, battery materials, and supply chain operations—not just retail or sales.One job listing specifically mentioned expertise in LFP and NMC battery materials, hinting that Tesla may be planning to source or produce batteries locally.Adding to the excitement, the Model Y was spotted test-driving in Mumbai, suggesting real-world trials are already underway.With over 1.4 billion people and a fast-growing demand for EVs, India has the potential to become Tesla’s next big growth engine—alongside the U.S. and China.

Can Tesla Survive 2025? 3 Red Flags Investors Shouldn’t Ignore📺 Watch the full video breakdown here → https://lnkd.in/gQPvrgwnTesla has always been a company that thrives on bold moves and ambitious visions—but as we head deeper into 2025, some critical challenges are emerging. In this post, we’ll explore three major developments that could significantly impact Tesla’s future—and what they mean for investors, owners, and fans of the company.⚠️ 1. Tesla’s Market Share in California Is Dropping FastCalifornia has long been Tesla’s stronghold—but recent data reveals a worrying trend. In Q1 2025, Tesla’s share of the EV market in California dropped to 43.9%, down from 55.5% a year earlier. That’s a 12-point decline in just one year.While Tesla’s registrations fell by 15%, other EV makers saw a 35% surge. The takeaway? Tesla isn’t just slowing down—its rivals are speeding up.Industry experts point to two main reasons:Tesla’s product lineup is aging, with limited updates to Models S, X, 3, and Y.Elon Musk’s political and social media activity may be turning off some buyers.While Model Y and Model 3 remain best-sellers, declining market share could impact resale values and Tesla’s overall brand power.💥 2. Cybercab and Semi Face Delays Due to TariffsAnother red flag: new tariffs may disrupt Tesla’s ambitious plans for next-gen vehicles like the Cybercab and the Semi truck.Reports indicate that tariffs on Chinese-made parts could rise as high as 145% under new trade policies. In response, Tesla has reportedly halted parts imports from China—potentially delaying the October 2025 prototype production and pushing back mass production to 2026.Tesla had previously absorbed tariffs up to 34%, but beyond that, costs become unsustainable.However, despite these hurdles, Tesla isn’t slowing down. The company is actively hiring for its Robotaxi division, including roles like Diagnostics Engineer, Robotaxi Operations—a clear sign it’s still investing in autonomous driving as a long-term growth engine.🌏 3. Tesla Accelerates Its Expansion Into IndiaWhile Tesla faces challenges in California and with supply chains, it’s also entering a massive new market—India.The company has posted over 25 job openings in India, many related to charging infrastructure, battery materials, and supply chain operations—not just retail or sales.One job listing specifically mentioned expertise in LFP and NMC battery materials, hinting that Tesla may be planning to source or produce batteries locally.Adding to the excitement, the Model Y was spotted test-driving in Mumbai, suggesting real-world trials are already underway.With over 1.4 billion people and a fast-growing demand for EVs, India has the potential to become Tesla’s next big growth engine—alongside the U.S. and China.

Can Tesla Survive 2025? 3 Red Flags Investors Shouldn’t Ignore📺 Watch the full video breakdown here → https://lnkd.in/gQPvrgwnTesla has always been a company that thrives on bold moves and ambitious visions—but as we head deeper into 2025, some critical challenges are emerging. In this post, we’ll explore three major developments that could significantly impact Tesla’s future—and what they mean for investors, owners, and fans of the company.⚠️ 1. Tesla’s Market Share in California Is Dropping FastCalifornia has long been Tesla’s stronghold—but recent data reveals a worrying trend. In Q1 2025, Tesla’s share of the EV market in California dropped to 43.9%, down from 55.5% a year earlier. That’s a 12-point decline in just one year.While Tesla’s registrations fell by 15%, other EV makers saw a 35% surge. The takeaway? Tesla isn’t just slowing down—its rivals are speeding up.Industry experts point to two main reasons:Tesla’s product lineup is aging, with limited updates to Models S, X, 3, and Y.Elon Musk’s political and social media activity may be turning off some buyers.While Model Y and Model 3 remain best-sellers, declining market share could impact resale values and Tesla’s overall brand power.💥 2. Cybercab and Semi Face Delays Due to TariffsAnother red flag: new tariffs may disrupt Tesla’s ambitious plans for next-gen vehicles like the Cybercab and the Semi truck.Reports indicate that tariffs on Chinese-made parts could rise as high as 145% under new trade policies. In response, Tesla has reportedly halted parts imports from China—potentially delaying the October 2025 prototype production and pushing back mass production to 2026.Tesla had previously absorbed tariffs up to 34%, but beyond that, costs become unsustainable.However, despite these hurdles, Tesla isn’t slowing down. The company is actively hiring for its Robotaxi division, including roles like Diagnostics Engineer, Robotaxi Operations—a clear sign it’s still investing in autonomous driving as a long-term growth engine.🌏 3. Tesla Accelerates Its Expansion Into IndiaWhile Tesla faces challenges in California and with supply chains, it’s also entering a massive new market—India.The company has posted over 25 job openings in India, many related to charging infrastructure, battery materials, and supply chain operations—not just retail or sales.One job listing specifically mentioned expertise in LFP and NMC battery materials, hinting that Tesla may be planning to source or produce batteries locally.Adding to the excitement, the Model Y was spotted test-driving in Mumbai, suggesting real-world trials are already underway.With over 1.4 billion people and a fast-growing demand for EVs, India has the potential to become Tesla’s next big growth engine—alongside the U.S. and China.

HIRING ALERTJob Title: Data Engineer – SAP HANA + Snowflake (Contract Role | Melbourne)Staff IT is hiring an experienced Data Engineer with a strong background in SAP HANA, Snowflake, and AWS for a contract role with a reputed client. If you're passionate about data engineering and ready to take on a high-impact role, this is the opportunity for you.📍 Location: Melbourne (Hybrid) 💰 Day Rate: $850 – $900 + GST 📆 Contract Duration: 6–12 monthsAbout the RoleAs a Data Engineer, you will be responsible for designing and implementing robust data pipelines and analytical solutions using SAP HANA and Snowflake. You'll work closely with cross-functional teams to enable scalable data access, transformation, and integration on cloud infrastructure (AWS).Key Responsibilities • Build and optimize scalable data pipelines across SAP HANA and Snowflake. • Integrate large datasets from diverse sources using best-in-class cloud practices. • Support data modeling and advanced analytics initiatives. • Collaborate with BI teams, architects, and business stakeholders. • Ensure performance tuning, security, and governance of data assets.Essential Skills & Experience • 8–10 years of relevant experience in data engineering roles. • Expertise in SAP HANA (modelling, data provisioning, performance tuning). • Hands-on experience with Snowflake (data sharing, warehouse modeling). • Proficiency in AWS data services (Glue, S3, Lambda, Redshift, etc.). • Strong SQL, scripting, and problem-solving skills. • Excellent communication and stakeholder management skills.📩 Apply Now Send your CV to deepak.a@staffit.com.au or comment below if you’re open to exploring this exciting opportunity.

IMMEDIATE HIRING!!Role: Process & Quality EngineerContract employment, Minimum 6 months.Medhini Group is a consultancy firm specializing in engineering and construction services for greenfield and brownfield industrial projects. With a strong network of government agencies, regulatory bodies, and investment agencies, we guide projects from conception to completion, including site selection and project charters. Our expertise lies in Industry 4.0 implementation, lean construction, bioreactor solutions, sustainability consulting, and science communication.Role DescriptionWe are looking for a motivated Engineer to support the efficiency and quality of our operations. This position will involve a blend of tasks focused on process improvement, adherence to standards, and ensuring product/service quality. The successful candidate will contribute to maintaining high operational standards and driving continuous improvement initiatives.Key Responsibilities:·      Assist in the development, optimization, and documentation of manufacturing or operational processes.·      Support the implementation of process improvements and efficiency initiatives.·      Collect and analyse process data to identify areas for enhancement and potential quality issues.·      Contribute to the creation and maintenance of Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) and work instructions, ensuring quality considerations are integrated.·      Participate in troubleshooting process-related issues, identifying root causes, and implementing corrective and preventive actions (CAPA).·      Assist in process validation and qualification activities.·      Support quality control activities, including inspections and testing, and provide feedback for process improvements.·      Help maintain accurate process and quality documentation and records.·      Support data collection and analysis for both process performance monitoring and quality metrics.·      Assist in ensuring compliance with relevant standards and regulations from both a process and quality perspective.Qualification:·      Degree in Microbiology, Biotechnology, Life Sciences, Pharmaceutical Sciences, Engineering, or related field.·      1–2 years’ experience in pharmaceutical, biotechnology, Semiconductor or Medical Devices manufacturing environments.·      Familiarity with Cleanroom and GMP standards is preferred.·      Strong attention to detail and observation skills.·      Flexible on working arrangement (vary depends on project).·      Good command of English (spoken and written) for documentation and reporting.Potential for Permanent Roles:Successful performance in this role, demonstrating a strong aptitude for both process and quality aspects, may lead to opportunities for permanent positions within the company.Click Can Tesla Survive 2025? 3 Red Flags Investors Shouldn’t Ignore📺 Watch the full video breakdown here → https://lnkd.in/gQPvrgwnTesla has always been a company that thrives on bold moves and ambitious visions—but as we head deeper into 2025, some critical challenges are emerging. In this post, we’ll explore three major developments that could significantly impact Tesla’s future—and what they mean for investors, owners, and fans of the company.⚠️ 1. Tesla’s Market Share in California Is Dropping FastCalifornia has long been Tesla’s stronghold—but recent data reveals a worrying trend. In Q1 2025, Tesla’s share of the EV market in California dropped to 43.9%, down from 55.5% a year earlier. That’s a 12-point decline in just one year.While Tesla’s registrations fell by 15%, other EV makers saw a 35% surge. The takeaway? Tesla isn’t just slowing down—its rivals are speeding up.Industry experts point to two main reasons:Tesla’s product lineup is aging, with limited updates to Models S, X, 3, and Y.Elon Musk’s political and social media activity may be turning off some buyers.While Model Y and Model 3 remain best-sellers, declining market share could impact resale values and Tesla’s overall brand power.💥 2. Cybercab and Semi Face Delays Due to TariffsAnother red flag: new tariffs may disrupt Tesla’s ambitious plans for next-gen vehicles like the Cybercab and the Semi truck.Reports indicate that tariffs on Chinese-made parts could rise as high as 145% under new trade policies. In response, Tesla has reportedly halted parts imports from China—potentially delaying the October 2025 prototype production and pushing back mass production to 2026.Tesla had previously absorbed tariffs up to 34%, but beyond that, costs become unsustainable.However, despite these hurdles, Tesla isn’t slowing down. The company is actively hiring for its Robotaxi division, including roles like Diagnostics Engineer, Robotaxi Operations—a clear sign it’s still investing in autonomous driving as a long-term growth engine.🌏 3. Tesla Accelerates Its Expansion Into IndiaWhile Tesla faces challenges in California and with supply chains, it’s also entering a massive new market—India.The company has posted over 25 job openings in India, many related to charging infrastructure, battery materials, and supply chain operations—not just retail or sales.One job listing specifically mentioned expertise in LFP and NMC battery materials, hinting that Tesla may be planning to source or produce batteries locally.Adding to the excitement, the Model Y was spotted test-driving in Mumbai, suggesting real-world trials are already underway.With over 1.4 billion people and a fast-growing demand for EVs, India has the potential to become Tesla’s next big growth engine—alongside the U.S. and China.

Not another social media series! 😩Here’s mine:A cover letter a day! Join me while I write cover letters to companies I’m applying to. My goal is to fill the cover letters with personality and make it less of a drag.Here’s my first one in the series:Dear Hiring Team,I'm a software engineer who builds full-stack applications that center people — their stories, their connections, their needs. When I came across TailorCare’s mission to make specialty care more personal and more effective, it resonated deeply with how I think about good technology: it should guide, empower, and remove friction from people’s lives.Most recently, I built Foodship, an application that helps people foster new friendships over shared meals. Users set up a profile, share their food preferences, pick a time, and get matched with others and a compatible restaurant. To support meaningful interactions, I use a chat completion model with a psychotherapist-inspired prompt to generate curated conversation questions designed to spark trust and reflection. I designed and built this app — front to back — using EJS, CSS/SCSS, Bootstrap, JavaScript, Node.js, Express.js, Passport.js, Socket.io, Agenda.js, Hugging Face API, and MongoDB.What draws me to TailorCare is the chance to collaborate across disciplines to build systems that are technically sound, human-centered, and impactful. Your work sits at the intersection of data, healthcare, and empathy — and that’s where I want to be. I bring a fast-learning mindset, clean code, and strong collaboration skills. I’m also no stranger to debugging odd issues at 2 a.m. or chasing down a race condition like it owes me money.Thanks for taking the time to read this. I’d love to connect and learn more about what you’re building at TailorCare.Warmly,Roosiel Agramonte

Can Tesla Survive 2025? 3 Red Flags Investors Shouldn’t Ignore📺 Watch the full video breakdown here → https://lnkd.in/gQPvrgwnTesla has always been a company that thrives on bold moves and ambitious visions—but as we head deeper into 2025, some critical challenges are emerging. In this post, we’ll explore three major developments that could significantly impact Tesla’s future—and what they mean for investors, owners, and fans of the company.⚠️ 1. Tesla’s Market Share in California Is Dropping FastCalifornia has long been Tesla’s stronghold—but recent data reveals a worrying trend. In Q1 2025, Tesla’s share of the EV market in California dropped to 43.9%, down from 55.5% a year earlier. That’s a 12-point decline in just one year.While Tesla’s registrations fell by 15%, other EV makers saw a 35% surge. The takeaway? Tesla isn’t just slowing down—its rivals are speeding up.Industry experts point to two main reasons:Tesla’s product lineup is aging, with limited updates to Models S, X, 3, and Y.Elon Musk’s political and social media activity may be turning off some buyers.While Model Y and Model 3 remain best-sellers, declining market share could impact resale values and Tesla’s overall brand power.💥 2. Cybercab and Semi Face Delays Due to TariffsAnother red flag: new tariffs may disrupt Tesla’s ambitious plans for next-gen vehicles like the Cybercab and the Semi truck.Reports indicate that tariffs on Chinese-made parts could rise as high as 145% under new trade policies. In response, Tesla has reportedly halted parts imports from China—potentially delaying the October 2025 prototype production and pushing back mass production to 2026.Tesla had previously absorbed tariffs up to 34%, but beyond that, costs become unsustainable.However, despite these hurdles, Tesla isn’t slowing down. The company is actively hiring for its Robotaxi division, including roles like Diagnostics Engineer, Robotaxi Operations—a clear sign it’s still investing in autonomous driving as a long-term growth engine.🌏 3. Tesla Accelerates Its Expansion Into IndiaWhile Tesla faces challenges in California and with supply chains, it’s also entering a massive new market—India.The company has posted over 25 job openings in India, many related to charging infrastructure, battery materials, and supply chain operations—not just retail or sales.One job listing specifically mentioned expertise in LFP and NMC battery materials, hinting that Tesla may be planning to source or produce batteries locally.Adding to the excitement, the Model Y was spotted test-driving in Mumbai, suggesting real-world trials are already underway.With over 1.4 billion people and a fast-growing demand for EVs, India has the potential to become Tesla’s next big growth engine—alongside the U.S. and China.

HIRING ALERTJob Title: Data Engineer – SAP HANA + Snowflake (Contract Role | Melbourne)Staff IT is hiring an experienced Data Engineer with a strong background in SAP HANA, Snowflake, and AWS for a contract role with a reputed client. If you're passionate about data engineering and ready to take on a high-impact role, this is the opportunity for you.📍 Location: Melbourne (Hybrid) 💰 Day Rate: $850 – $900 + GST 📆 Contract Duration: 6–12 monthsAbout the RoleAs a Data Engineer, you will be responsible for designing and implementing robust data pipelines and analytical solutions using SAP HANA and Snowflake. You'll work closely with cross-functional teams to enable scalable data access, transformation, and integration on cloud infrastructure (AWS).Key Responsibilities • Build and optimize scalable data pipelines across SAP HANA and Snowflake. • Integrate large datasets from diverse sources using best-in-class cloud practices. • Support data modeling and advanced analytics initiatives. • Collaborate with BI teams, architects, and business stakeholders. • Ensure performance tuning, security, and governance of data assets.Essential Skills & Experience • 8–10 years of relevant experience in data engineering roles. • Expertise in SAP HANA (modelling, data provisioning, performance tuning). • Hands-on experience with Snowflake (data sharing, warehouse modeling). • Proficiency in AWS data services (Glue, S3, Lambda, Redshift, etc.). • Strong SQL, scripting, and problem-solving skills. • Excellent communication and stakeholder management skills.📩 Apply Now Send your CV to deepak.a@staffit.com.au or comment below if you’re open to exploring this exciting opportunity.

IMMEDIATE HIRING!!Role: Process & Quality EngineerContract employment, Minimum 6 months.Medhini Group is a consultancy firm specializing in engineering and construction services for greenfield and brownfield industrial projects. With a strong network of government agencies, regulatory bodies, and investment agencies, we guide projects from conception to completion, including site selection and project charters. Our expertise lies in Industry 4.0 implementation, lean construction, bioreactor solutions, sustainability consulting, and science communication.Role DescriptionWe are looking for a motivated Engineer to support the efficiency and quality of our operations. This position will involve a blend of tasks focused on process improvement, adherence to standards, and ensuring product/service quality. The successful candidate will contribute to maintaining high operational standards and driving continuous improvement initiatives.Key Responsibilities:·      Assist in the development, optimization, and documentation of manufacturing or operational processes.·      Support the implementation of process improvements and efficiency initiatives.·      Collect and analyse process data to identify areas for enhancement and potential quality issues.·      Contribute to the creation and maintenance of Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) and work instructions, ensuring quality considerations are integrated.·      Participate in troubleshooting process-related issues, identifying root causes, and implementing corrective and preventive actions (CAPA).·      Assist in process validation and qualification activities.·      Support quality control activities, including inspections and testing, and provide feedback for process improvements.·      Help maintain accurate process and quality documentation and records.·      Support data collection and analysis for both process performance monitoring and quality metrics.·      Assist in ensuring compliance with relevant standards and regulations from both a process and quality perspective.Qualification:·      Degree in Microbiology, Biotechnology, Life Sciences, Pharmaceutical Sciences, Engineering, or related field.·      1–2 years’ experience in pharmaceutical, biotechnology, Semiconductor or Medical Devices manufacturing environments.·      Familiarity with Cleanroom and GMP standards is preferred.·      Strong attention to detail and observation skills.·      Flexible on working arrangement (vary depends on project).·      Good command of English (spoken and written) for documentation and reporting.Potential for Permanent Roles:Successful performance in this role, demonstrating a strong aptitude for both process and quality aspects, may lead to opportunities for permanent positions within the company.Click Not another social media series! 😩Here’s mine:A cover letter a day! Join me while I write cover letters to companies I’m applying to. My goal is to fill the cover letters with personality and make it less of a drag.Here’s my first one in the series:Dear Hiring Team,I'm a software engineer who builds full-stack applications that center people — their stories, their connections, their needs. When I came across TailorCare’s mission to make specialty care more personal and more effective, it resonated deeply with how I think about good technology: it should guide, empower, and remove friction from people’s lives.Most recently, I built Foodship, an application that helps people foster new friendships over shared meals. Users set up a profile, share their food preferences, pick a time, and get matched with others and a compatible restaurant. To support meaningful interactions, I use a chat completion model with a psychotherapist-inspired prompt to generate curated conversation questions designed to spark trust and reflection. I designed and built this app — front to back — using EJS, CSS/SCSS, Bootstrap, JavaScript, Node.js, Express.js, Passport.js, Socket.io, Agenda.js, Hugging Face API, and MongoDB.What draws me to TailorCare is the chance to collaborate across disciplines to build systems that are technically sound, human-centered, and impactful. Your work sits at the intersection of data, healthcare, and empathy — and that’s where I want to be. I bring a fast-learning mindset, clean code, and strong collaboration skills. I’m also no stranger to debugging odd issues at 2 a.m. or chasing down a race condition like it owes me money.Thanks for taking the time to read this. I’d love to connect and learn more about what you’re building at TailorCare.Warmly,Roosiel Agramonte

Can Tesla Survive 2025? 3 Red Flags Investors Shouldn’t Ignore📺 Watch the full video breakdown here → https://lnkd.in/gQPvrgwnTesla has always been a company that thrives on bold moves and ambitious visions—but as we head deeper into 2025, some critical challenges are emerging. In this post, we’ll explore three major developments that could significantly impact Tesla’s future—and what they mean for investors, owners, and fans of the company.⚠️ 1. Tesla’s Market Share in California Is Dropping FastCalifornia has long been Tesla’s stronghold—but recent data reveals a worrying trend. In Q1 2025, Tesla’s share of the EV market in California dropped to 43.9%, down from 55.5% a year earlier. That’s a 12-point decline in just one year.While Tesla’s registrations fell by 15%, other EV makers saw a 35% surge. The takeaway? Tesla isn’t just slowing down—its rivals are speeding up.Industry experts point to two main reasons:Tesla’s product lineup is aging, with limited updates to Models S, X, 3, and Y.Elon Musk’s political and social media activity may be turning off some buyers.While Model Y and Model 3 remain best-sellers, declining market share could impact resale values and Tesla’s overall brand power.💥 2. Cybercab and Semi Face Delays Due to TariffsAnother red flag: new tariffs may disrupt Tesla’s ambitious plans for next-gen vehicles like the Cybercab and the Semi truck.Reports indicate that tariffs on Chinese-made parts could rise as high as 145% under new trade policies. In response, Tesla has reportedly halted parts imports from China—potentially delaying the October 2025 prototype production and pushing back mass production to 2026.Tesla had previously absorbed tariffs up to 34%, but beyond that, costs become unsustainable.However, despite these hurdles, Tesla isn’t slowing down. The company is actively hiring for its Robotaxi division, including roles like Diagnostics Engineer, Robotaxi Operations—a clear sign it’s still investing in autonomous driving as a long-term growth engine.🌏 3. Tesla Accelerates Its Expansion Into IndiaWhile Tesla faces challenges in California and with supply chains, it’s also entering a massive new market—India.The company has posted over 25 job openings in India, many related to charging infrastructure, battery materials, and supply chain operations—not just retail or sales.One job listing specifically mentioned expertise in LFP and NMC battery materials, hinting that Tesla may be planning to source or produce batteries locally.Adding to the excitement, the Model Y was spotted test-driving in Mumbai, suggesting real-world trials are already underway.With over 1.4 billion people and a fast-growing demand for EVs, India has the potential to become Tesla’s next big growth engine—alongside the U.S. and China.

Not another social media series! 😩Here’s mine:A cover letter a day! Join me while I write cover letters to companies I’m applying to. My goal is to fill the cover letters with personality and make it less of a drag.Here’s my first one in the series:Dear Hiring Team,I'm a software engineer who builds full-stack applications that center people — their stories, their connections, their needs. When I came across TailorCare’s mission to make specialty care more personal and more effective, it resonated deeply with how I think about good technology: it should guide, empower, and remove friction from people’s lives.Most recently, I built Foodship, an application that helps people foster new friendships over shared meals. Users set up a profile, share their food preferences, pick a time, and get matched with others and a compatible restaurant. To support meaningful interactions, I use a chat completion model with a psychotherapist-inspired prompt to generate curated conversation questions designed to spark trust and reflection. I designed and built this app — front to back — using EJS, CSS/SCSS, Bootstrap, JavaScript, Node.js, Express.js, Passport.js, Socket.io, Agenda.js, Hugging Face API, and MongoDB.What draws me to TailorCare is the chance to collaborate across disciplines to build systems that are technically sound, human-centered, and impactful. Your work sits at the intersection of data, healthcare, and empathy — and that’s where I want to be. I bring a fast-learning mindset, clean code, and strong collaboration skills. I’m also no stranger to debugging odd issues at 2 a.m. or chasing down a race condition like it owes me money.Thanks for taking the time to read this. I’d love to connect and learn more about what you’re building at TailorCare.Warmly,Roosiel Agramonte

Can Tesla Survive 2025? 3 Red Flags Investors Shouldn’t Ignore📺 Watch the full video breakdown here → https://lnkd.in/gQPvrgwnTesla has always been a company that thrives on bold moves and ambitious visions—but as we head deeper into 2025, some critical challenges are emerging. In this post, we’ll explore three major developments that could significantly impact Tesla’s future—and what they mean for investors, owners, and fans of the company.⚠️ 1. Tesla’s Market Share in California Is Dropping FastCalifornia has long been Tesla’s stronghold—but recent data reveals a worrying trend. In Q1 2025, Tesla’s share of the EV market in California dropped to 43.9%, down from 55.5% a year earlier. That’s a 12-point decline in just one year.While Tesla’s registrations fell by 15%, other EV makers saw a 35% surge. The takeaway? Tesla isn’t just slowing down—its rivals are speeding up.Industry experts point to two main reasons:Tesla’s product lineup is aging, with limited updates to Models S, X, 3, and Y.Elon Musk’s political and social media activity may be turning off some buyers.While Model Y and Model 3 remain best-sellers, declining market share could impact resale values and Tesla’s overall brand power.💥 2. Cybercab and Semi Face Delays Due to TariffsAnother red flag: new tariffs may disrupt Tesla’s ambitious plans for next-gen vehicles like the Cybercab and the Semi truck.Reports indicate that tariffs on Chinese-made parts could rise as high as 145% under new trade policies. In response, Tesla has reportedly halted parts imports from China—potentially delaying the October 2025 prototype production and pushing back mass production to 2026.Tesla had previously absorbed tariffs up to 34%, but beyond that, costs become unsustainable.However, despite these hurdles, Tesla isn’t slowing down. The company is actively hiring for its Robotaxi division, including roles like Diagnostics Engineer, Robotaxi Operations—a clear sign it’s still investing in autonomous driving as a long-term growth engine.🌏 3. Tesla Accelerates Its Expansion Into IndiaWhile Tesla faces challenges in California and with supply chains, it’s also entering a massive new market—India.The company has posted over 25 job openings in India, many related to charging infrastructure, battery materials, and supply chain operations—not just retail or sales.One job listing specifically mentioned expertise in LFP and NMC battery materials, hinting that Tesla may be planning to source or produce batteries locally.Adding to the excitement, the Model Y was spotted test-driving in Mumbai, suggesting real-world trials are already underway.With over 1.4 billion people and a fast-growing demand for EVs, India has the potential to become Tesla’s next big growth engine—alongside the U.S. and China.

Not another social media series! 😩Here’s mine:A cover letter a day! Join me while I write cover letters to companies I’m applying to. My goal is to fill the cover letters with personality and make it less of a drag.Here’s my first one in the series:Dear Hiring Team,I'm a software engineer who builds full-stack applications that center people — their stories, their connections, their needs. When I came across TailorCare’s mission to make specialty care more personal and more effective, it resonated deeply with how I think about good technology: it should guide, empower, and remove friction from people’s lives.Most recently, I built Foodship, an application that helps people foster new friendships over shared meals. Users set up a profile, share their food preferences, pick a time, and get matched with others and a compatible restaurant. To support meaningful interactions, I use a chat completion model with a psychotherapist-inspired prompt to generate curated conversation questions designed to spark trust and reflection. I designed and built this app — front to back — using EJS, CSS/SCSS, Bootstrap, JavaScript, Node.js, Express.js, Passport.js, Socket.io, Agenda.js, Hugging Face API, and MongoDB.What draws me to TailorCare is the chance to collaborate across disciplines to build systems that are technically sound, human-centered, and impactful. Your work sits at the intersection of data, healthcare, and empathy — and that’s where I want to be. I bring a fast-learning mindset, clean code, and strong collaboration skills. I’m also no stranger to debugging odd issues at 2 a.m. or chasing down a race condition like it owes me money.Thanks for taking the time to read this. I’d love to connect and learn more about what you’re building at TailorCare.Warmly,Roosiel Agramonte

Can Tesla Survive 2025? 3 Red Flags Investors Shouldn’t Ignore📺 Watch the full video breakdown here → https://lnkd.in/gQPvrgwnTesla has always been a company that thrives on bold moves and ambitious visions—but as we head deeper into 2025, some critical challenges are emerging. In this post, we’ll explore three major developments that could significantly impact Tesla’s future—and what they mean for investors, owners, and fans of the company.⚠️ 1. Tesla’s Market Share in California Is Dropping FastCalifornia has long been Tesla’s stronghold—but recent data reveals a worrying trend. In Q1 2025, Tesla’s share of the EV market in California dropped to 43.9%, down from 55.5% a year earlier. That’s a 12-point decline in just one year.While Tesla’s registrations fell by 15%, other EV makers saw a 35% surge. The takeaway? Tesla isn’t just slowing down—its rivals are speeding up.Industry experts point to two main reasons:Tesla’s product lineup is aging, with limited updates to Models S, X, 3, and Y.Elon Musk’s political and social media activity may be turning off some buyers.While Model Y and Model 3 remain best-sellers, declining market share could impact resale values and Tesla’s overall brand power.💥 2. Cybercab and Semi Face Delays Due to TariffsAnother red flag: new tariffs may disrupt Tesla’s ambitious plans for next-gen vehicles like the Cybercab and the Semi truck.Reports indicate that tariffs on Chinese-made parts could rise as high as 145% under new trade policies. In response, Tesla has reportedly halted parts imports from China—potentially delaying the October 2025 prototype production and pushing back mass production to 2026.Tesla had previously absorbed tariffs up to 34%, but beyond that, costs become unsustainable.However, despite these hurdles, Tesla isn’t slowing down. The company is actively hiring for its Robotaxi division, including roles like Diagnostics Engineer, Robotaxi Operations—a clear sign it’s still investing in autonomous driving as a long-term growth engine.🌏 3. Tesla Accelerates Its Expansion Into IndiaWhile Tesla faces challenges in California and with supply chains, it’s also entering a massive new market—India.The company has posted over 25 job openings in India, many related to charging infrastructure, battery materials, and supply chain operations—not just retail or sales.One job listing specifically mentioned expertise in LFP and NMC battery materials, hinting that Tesla may be planning to source or produce batteries locally.Adding to the excitement, the Model Y was spotted test-driving in Mumbai, suggesting real-world trials are already underway.With over 1.4 billion people and a fast-growing demand for EVs, India has the potential to become Tesla’s next big growth engine—alongside the U.S. and China.

Not another social media series! 😩Here’s mine:A cover letter a day! Join me while I write cover letters to companies I’m applying to. My goal is to fill the cover letters with personality and make it less of a drag.Here’s my first one in the series:Dear Hiring Team,I'm a software engineer who builds full-stack applications that center people — their stories, their connections, their needs. When I came across TailorCare’s mission to make specialty care more personal and more effective, it resonated deeply with how I think about good technology: it should guide, empower, and remove friction from people’s lives.Most recently, I built Foodship, an application that helps people foster new friendships over shared meals. Users set up a profile, share their food preferences, pick a time, and get matched with others and a compatible restaurant. To support meaningful interactions, I use a chat completion model with a psychotherapist-inspired prompt to generate curated conversation questions designed to spark trust and reflection. I designed and built this app — front to back — using EJS, CSS/SCSS, Bootstrap, JavaScript, Node.js, Express.js, Passport.js, Socket.io, Agenda.js, Hugging Face API, and MongoDB.What draws me to TailorCare is the chance to collaborate across disciplines to build systems that are technically sound, human-centered, and impactful. Your work sits at the intersection of data, healthcare, and empathy — and that’s where I want to be. I bring a fast-learning mindset, clean code, and strong collaboration skills. I’m also no stranger to debugging odd issues at 2 a.m. or chasing down a race condition like it owes me money.Thanks for taking the time to read this. I’d love to connect and learn more about what you’re building at TailorCare.Warmly,Roosiel Agramonte

Can Tesla Survive 2025? 3 Red Flags Investors Shouldn’t Ignore📺 Watch the full video breakdown here → https://lnkd.in/gQPvrgwnTesla has always been a company that thrives on bold moves and ambitious visions—but as we head deeper into 2025, some critical challenges are emerging. In this post, we’ll explore three major developments that could significantly impact Tesla’s future—and what they mean for investors, owners, and fans of the company.⚠️ 1. Tesla’s Market Share in California Is Dropping FastCalifornia has long been Tesla’s stronghold—but recent data reveals a worrying trend. In Q1 2025, Tesla’s share of the EV market in California dropped to 43.9%, down from 55.5% a year earlier. That’s a 12-point decline in just one year.While Tesla’s registrations fell by 15%, other EV makers saw a 35% surge. The takeaway? Tesla isn’t just slowing down—its rivals are speeding up.Industry experts point to two main reasons:Tesla’s product lineup is aging, with limited updates to Models S, X, 3, and Y.Elon Musk’s political and social media activity may be turning off some buyers.While Model Y and Model 3 remain best-sellers, declining market share could impact resale values and Tesla’s overall brand power.💥 2. Cybercab and Semi Face Delays Due to TariffsAnother red flag: new tariffs may disrupt Tesla’s ambitious plans for next-gen vehicles like the Cybercab and the Semi truck.Reports indicate that tariffs on Chinese-made parts could rise as high as 145% under new trade policies. In response, Tesla has reportedly halted parts imports from China—potentially delaying the October 2025 prototype production and pushing back mass production to 2026.Tesla had previously absorbed tariffs up to 34%, but beyond that, costs become unsustainable.However, despite these hurdles, Tesla isn’t slowing down. The company is actively hiring for its Robotaxi division, including roles like Diagnostics Engineer, Robotaxi Operations—a clear sign it’s still investing in autonomous driving as a long-term growth engine.🌏 3. Tesla Accelerates Its Expansion Into IndiaWhile Tesla faces challenges in California and with supply chains, it’s also entering a massive new market—India.The company has posted over 25 job openings in India, many related to charging infrastructure, battery materials, and supply chain operations—not just retail or sales.One job listing specifically mentioned expertise in LFP and NMC battery materials, hinting that Tesla may be planning to source or produce batteries locally.Adding to the excitement, the Model Y was spotted test-driving in Mumbai, suggesting real-world trials are already underway.With over 1.4 billion people and a fast-growing demand for EVs, India has the potential to become Tesla’s next big growth engine—alongside the U.S. and China.

integrated.·      Participate in troubleshooting process-related issues, identifying root causes, and implementing corrective and preventive actions (CAPA).·      Assist in process validation and qualification activities.·      Support quality control activities, including inspections and testing, and provide feedback for process improvements.·      Help maintain accurate process and quality documentation and records.·      Support data collection and analysis for both process performance monitoring and quality metrics.·      Assist in ensuring compliance with relevant standards and regulations from both a process and quality perspective.Qualification:·      Degree in Microbiology, Biotechnology, Life Sciences, Pharmaceutical Sciences, Engineering, or related field.·      1–2 years’ experience in pharmaceutical, biotechnology, Semiconductor or Medical Devices manufacturing environments.·      Familiarity with Cleanroom and GMP standards is preferred.·      Strong attention to detail and observation skills.·      Flexible on working arrangement (vary depends on project).·      Good command of English (spoken and written) for documentation and reporting.Potential for Not another social media series! 😩Here’s mine:A cover letter a day! Join me while I write cover letters to companies I’m applying to. My goal is to fill the cover letters with personality and make it less of a drag.Here’s my first one in the series:Dear Hiring Team,I'm a software engineer who builds full-stack applications that center people — their stories, their connections, their needs. When I came across TailorCare’s mission to make specialty care more personal and more effective, it resonated deeply with how I think about good technology: it should guide, empower, and remove friction from people’s lives.Most recently, I built Foodship, an application that helps people foster new friendships over shared meals. Users set up a profile, share their food preferences, pick a time, and get matched with others and a compatible restaurant. To support meaningful interactions, I use a chat completion model with a psychotherapist-inspired prompt to generate curated conversation questions designed to spark trust and reflection. I designed and built this app — front to back — using EJS, CSS/SCSS, Bootstrap, JavaScript, Node.js, Express.js, Passport.js, Socket.io, Agenda.js, Hugging Face API, and MongoDB.What draws me to TailorCare is the chance to collaborate across disciplines to build systems that are technically sound, human-centered, and impactful. Your work sits at the intersection of data, healthcare, and empathy — and that’s where I want to be. I bring a fast-learning mindset, clean code, and strong collaboration skills. I’m also no stranger to debugging odd issues at 2 a.m. or chasing down a race condition like it owes me money.Thanks for taking the time to read this. I’d love to connect and learn more about what you’re building at TailorCare.Warmly,Roosiel Agramonte

Can Tesla Survive 2025? 3 Red Flags Investors Shouldn’t Ignore📺 Watch the full video breakdown here → https://lnkd.in/gQPvrgwnTesla has always been a company that thrives on bold moves and ambitious visions—but as we head deeper into 2025, some critical challenges are emerging. In this post, we’ll explore three major developments that could significantly impact Tesla’s future—and what they mean for investors, owners, and fans of the company.⚠️ 1. Tesla’s Market Share in California Is Dropping FastCalifornia has long been Tesla’s stronghold—but recent data reveals a worrying trend. In Q1 2025, Tesla’s share of the EV market in California dropped to 43.9%, down from 55.5% a year earlier. That’s a 12-point decline in just one year.While Tesla’s registrations fell by 15%, other EV makers saw a 35% surge. The takeaway? Tesla isn’t just slowing down—its rivals are speeding up.Industry experts point to two main reasons:Tesla’s product lineup is aging, with limited updates to Models S, X, 3, and Y.Elon Musk’s political and social media activity may be turning off some buyers.While Model Y and Model 3 remain best-sellers, declining market share could impact resale values and Tesla’s overall brand power.💥 2. Cybercab and Semi Face Delays Due to TariffsAnother red flag: new tariffs may disrupt Tesla’s ambitious plans for next-gen vehicles like the Cybercab and the Semi truck.Reports indicate that tariffs on Chinese-made parts could rise as high as 145% under new trade policies. In response, Tesla has reportedly halted parts imports from China—potentially delaying the October 2025 prototype production and pushing back mass production to 2026.Tesla had previously absorbed tariffs up to 34%, but beyond that, costs become unsustainable.However, despite these hurdles, Tesla isn’t slowing down. The company is actively hiring for its Robotaxi division, including roles like Diagnostics Engineer, Robotaxi Operations—a clear sign it’s still investing in autonomous driving as a long-term growth engine.🌏 3. Tesla Accelerates Its Expansion Into IndiaWhile Tesla faces challenges in California and with supply chains, it’s also entering a massive new market—India.The company has posted over 25 job openings in India, many related to charging infrastructure, battery materials, and supply chain operations—not just retail or sales.One job listing specifically mentioned expertise in LFP and NMC battery materials, hinting that Tesla may be planning to source or produce batteries locally.Adding to the excitement, the Model Y was spotted test-driving in Mumbai, suggesting real-world trials are already underway.With over 1.4 billion people and a fast-growing demand for EVs, India has the potential to become Tesla’s next big growth engine—alongside the U.S. and China.
